content: The "Consumer Credit Card Protection Act of 2005" prohibits universal defaults on credit card accounts. BOX DISCLOSURE OF PAYMENT PERIOD FOR MINIMUM PAYMENTS ON CREDIT CARD BALANCE. Section 127(b) of the Truth in Lending Act is amended to include new requirements for minimum payment terms on credit card statements. This includes clear and conspicuous repayment information for the outstanding balance, minimum monthly payment in both dollar figure and percentage, and the estimated number of months to pay off the balance by making only minimum payments. The Truth in Lending Act is amended to include new requirements for minimum payment terms on credit card statements, ensuring clear repayment information. Creditors must disclose applicable annual percentage rates without regard to fixed or variable rates. The disclosure of temporary or introductory interest rates must be based on the annual percentage rate in effect at the time of disclosure and an interest rate determined by an index or formula for subsequent adjustments. The disclosure is made for the remainder of the amortization period. SEC. 4. ADVANCED NOTICE REQUIRED BEFORE INCREASING RATES OR FEES ON CREDIT CARD ACCOUNTS. Section 127 of the Truth in Lending Act is amended to require advance notice of any increase in interest rates or fees on credit card accounts. Increases cannot take effect before the beginning of the billing cycle that starts at least 30 days after the obligor receives a specific notice. The Truth in Lending Act now requires advance notice of any increase in interest rates or fees on credit card accounts. Increases cannot take effect before the beginning of the billing cycle that starts at least 30 days after the obligor receives a specific notice. The Truth in Lending Act mandates that any notice regarding fee imposition must be sent separately to the consumer without any advertising or disclosures. The notice should also explain the reasons for the fee, when it will be imposed, and the options available to the consumer.
